Quantum theory is often described as a theory of states on a suitable algebra of observables. However, this description is not mathematically precise. We provide a precise mathematical description of quantum theory in terms of a category of Hilbert spaces and operators on them. This description is based on a categorical approach to foundations of mathematics, which is more precise and more general than the traditional approach based on analysis.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest to the scientific community because of their extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and the genome of a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the bare minimum, with a small genome and a large number of genes that are not required for the development of a free-living organism. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the main factors that contribute to the severity of a disease. In this study, we describe a mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of the cargo-receptor complex and disrupt nuclear import. This mechanism of viral antagonism is a common strategy used by many viruses to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to escape the antiviral response and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of proton channels. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the zinc-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the effects is uncertain. Here, we quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields and yield variability in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large mammal in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in diet composition. Our results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of niche partitioning in the ecology and evolution of large mammal assemblages. It also provides a model for the application of DNA metabarcoding to the study of niche partitioning in other systems.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses in the United States during the early stages of the COVID-19 crisis. Our findings suggest that the crisis is already having a devastating impact on small businesses. Many businesses have already laid off workers and are closing. Businesses are also financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses are relying on the CARES Act to access financial support, but many anticipate problems accessing the program. These findings have important implications for policymakers and small businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, and that most of it is concentrated in convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This distribution is mostly due to the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of plastic, which are rapidly degraded into smaller particles. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is the only place in the universe where life exists. We determined the age of 40 large presolar grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. These grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This work is important for understanding the origin of the solar system. It is also important for understanding the origin of life.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Alpha-synuclein (α-syn) is a protein that is involved in a variety of human diseases, including multiple system atrophy (MSA). MSA is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising therapeutic agent for the treatment of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to limit α-syn aggregation and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. (truncated)

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. It also controls the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. This paper describes the nature of the communication system that controls these functions. The communication system is a network of cells that is highly connected and has a small-world configuration. This configuration is effective for both local and global communication and is therefore highly efficient. The findings are important for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not available elsewhere. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also highly dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can be altered by the host, the environment, and the gut microbiome itself. This study provides evidence that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the microbiome. This study also provides a resource for the discovery of natural products from anaerobic fungi.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, and the study of the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon is of great interest. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high probability of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats. We also identify a key role for brain energy metabolism in the establishment of social hierarchy and show that this is mediated by the nucleus accumbens. Our findings point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new treatments for social anxiety disorder. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we develop a strategy to synthesize and assemble materials into structures that exhibit desired responses. The synthesized structures are highly programmable and can be easily tailored to different applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and manufacture of mechanical devices with desired responses. It also provides a platform for the development of new materials and structures with specific responses.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, a downstream element of the let-7 pathway, can mediate the reversal of the adult hemoglobin system toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This reversal is achieved by a reduction in the expression of the adult hemoglobin alpha chain and a concomitant increase in the expression of the fetal hemoglobin alpha chain. This work provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. This work may also have implications for the evolution of hemoglobin in vertebrates. (Show more)

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to available therapies. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and the fatty acid desaturase stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), and is dependent on the mTORC1 pathway. We also found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction in preclinical models resulted in near-complete tumor regression. These findings provide a rationale for the development of combination therapies for cancer patients with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutations. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are used in millions of patients worldwide. However, the mechanism of action of these drugs is not fully understood. Here, we show that these drugs activate a Ca2+ signaling pathway that is involved in the development of heart failure. This pathway is involved in the development of heart failure and may be a target for the development of new drugs.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for forest conservation in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring, and used adaptive management to address uncertainties. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but that the policy failed to halt the decline of older forests. This failure is partly explained by the continued expansion of clearcutting on private lands. The NWFP is a model for policy that uses science to address uncertainties, but our findings suggest that it is not yet sufficient to halt the decline of older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. It also demonstrates the potential of computational approaches in the early stages of drug development. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes. (Show more)

We introduce a new deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting network is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of parameters, and is easy to train and apply. We show that the proposed network architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems. The proposed network architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply, and can be used in a wide range of problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice, which is increasing in popularity, has a negative impact on sleep. The results show that the use of electronic devices before bedtime phase-delay the circadian clock, acutely suppress melatonin, and reduce alertness the following morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium (Os) in these samples. In contrast, bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania exhibit 187Os/188Os ratios <<1.0 and at face value suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the adult is not well understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the adult, and that its function is not limited to the development of autoimmunity. We also show that CTLA-4 deletion can be used to study the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity in the adult.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, and to trace the evolution of beetle species, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cell wall-degrading enzymes. These results provide insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. They also have implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity in general. (Show more)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have the potential to evade the immune protection afforded by vaccines and prior infection. This study demonstrates the utility of a deep learning algorithm in the optimization of an antibody that is effective against the Delta variant. The algorithm can be used to identify CDR changes that can improve the binding affinity of antibodies against VOCs. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules and may be useful in the development of new antibody drug candidates to combat the emerging VOCs.

We report the results of a large-scale experiment in which participants were exposed to the same technology (paper planes) but learned from different numbers of models (1, 2, or 4). We found that larger populations did not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of the technology. This result is important because it suggests that the size of the population is not the only factor that determines the rate of cultural evolution. Our results also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to the process of innovation and adaptation.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is the sixth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with a ∼12-fold decreased risk. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a brittle boundary. The inner core is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth, and its formation is still a mystery. The formation of the inner core is a crystallization process, and the nucleation of the solid phase is the first step of crystallization. However, the nucleation of the stable, hexagonal, close-packed (hcp) phase of iron, which is the main component of the inner core, has been shown to require an unrealistic degree of undercooling. This contradiction is referred to as the inner core nucleation paradox. We show that the nucleation of the stable, body-centered, cubic (bcc) phase of iron, which is also the main component of the inner core, is much more likely to occur under inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the addictive behaviors associated with chronic marijuana use.

Language is the most complex and sophisticated form of communication. It is also unique in the extent to which it is processed by the human brain. This has led to the hypothesis that language processing is mediated by a special mechanism, the “language comprehension system.” Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in language processing, which are trained on unrelated tasks, are able to predict the brain activity of humans performing language comprehension tasks. This suggests that the language comprehension system is a fundamental computational mechanism in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still in its infancy. It is now entering scientific computing, but it is not clear whether it can be used in scientific computing. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a paradox, and we explain it by showing that the existence of stable NNs is not sufficient for the existence of algorithms that can train them. We introduce a new algorithm that is stable and fast. This algorithm is a major step toward the use of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a unique opportunity to reflect on the nature of science and the role of science in society. This paper discusses the role of science in the COVID-19 pandemic, with a focus on the role of psychology in the pandemic’s response.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause infection of the peripheral and central nervous systems and skin, respectively. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with the reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We find that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the ancient leprosy bacterium than is M. leprae, and that they have retained similar functions. This suggests that despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This work provides a foundation for understanding the evolution of leprosy and the mechanisms that have led to the development of the two distinct leprosy diseases. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science. They are also the two key concepts standing at the foundations of quantum and statistical mechanics. In this paper, we show that the entanglement dynamics in isolated quantum systems is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement. This result is obtained by combining integrability with the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, and there is a need for a vaccine that is safe, effective, and easy to produce on a large scale. Here, we describe a vaccine that is safe, effective, and easy to produce on a large scale. This vaccine is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain that is protected from furin cleavage. This vaccine is currently in clinical development.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with some studies suggesting that it was spread by rats, while others suggest that it was spread by human ectoparasite vectors. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits the mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a mechanistic model to understand the history of a disease.

The evolution of brain size is a major topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is not the only one. The number of neurons is the brain’s basic computational unit and is more relevant to cognition. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a molecular basis for the role of TRAP1 as a tumor suppressor. (truncated)

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, which is the network of filaments that organizes the shape of cells. They are also the main components of many cellular processes, such as cell motility. However, the cytoskeleton is dynamic, and filaments are constantly being assembled and disassembled. This process is tightly regulated by proteins that bind and unbind to filaments, thereby controlling their lifetime. Here, we show that one of these proteins, cofilin, can sever filaments by binding to them. We show that this process is enhanced by mechanical forces, such as those generated by the flow of fluids. This finding is important for understanding the role of cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose ingestion relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose. The results also suggest that the brain may play a role in the different appetite-suppressing effects of these two sugars. This may have important implications for the development of strategies to reduce food intake.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries, and that the distribution of African and Asian ancestry is not homogeneous across the island. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar, and for the study of the human population dynamics in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people experience the same emotions without their awareness. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, and for the study of the psychology of emotion.

The ribosome is the molecular machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is a critical determinant of protein synthesis, but the ribosome can also modify the mRNA sequence in a number of ways. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can have a modest impact on protein synthesis. This work provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in the ribosome and protein synthesis. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is one of the most striking features of mammalian evolution. This study shows that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. It replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold.

The type IV pili of bacteria are involved in a wide range of functions, including twitching motility, surface attachment, and sensing of the environment. Here we show that the type IV pili of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa are also involved in sensing the environment. This sensing is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system, which regulates the production of cAMP and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. The Chp system is activated by the mechanical activity of the pili, which are used as a mechanosensitive sensor. This mechanosensitive system is important for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa, as it promotes long-term attachment to surfaces, which is a key step in the pathogenesis of this bacterium. Our findings provide insight into the role of pili in sensing the environment and the regulation of virulence. They also suggest that the type IV pili of bacteria are involved in a wider range of functions than previously thought. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is not well understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the blood of free-living white-tailed deer. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our findings highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the reasons for the growth of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the challenges of moving toward sustainable practices. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is characterized by chronic inflammation, which is most often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to amyloid-β (Aβ) plaque deposits and cell death. However, this response is not observed in transgenic animal models devoid of such pathologies, suggesting that the underlying processes may be more complex. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, are capable of producing a variety of potent immune factors, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. These findings reveal a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles. Thus, we propose that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a new perspective on the disease and may lead to the development of novel therapeutics. (Show more)

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, its origin and early history remain unclear. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. This study shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results suggest that the folding of a protein is not a single process but rather a series of processes. This study also shows that the folding of a protein can be studied at high structural resolution by a new method that measures the extent to which the protein is chemically protected in the early stages of folding. This method is expected to be useful for studying the folding of other proteins. This study is a step toward understanding the complex process of protein folding. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and have been shown to function as precursors to RNA caps. Here, we show that one of the enzymes that removes those caps, a pyrophosphohydrolase, preferentially deprotects capped RNAs over their counterparts that are tri- or diphosphorylated. This enzyme recognizes capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which this enzyme recognizes capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. This work provides a unique perspective on the role of RNA in the stress response and the evolution of cellular defense mechanisms. (Show more)

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Although there are several treatments for sepsis, there is no specific therapy to restore immune function. Here, we show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. This strategy could be used in the development of new clinical trials.

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon on Earth. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Here, we provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We show that plants are the dominant kingdom, and that animals are the most abundant taxon within plants. We also show that humans have a disproportionately large impact on the biomass of mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of humans on the biosphere.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical stability. It is used in many applications, including in cutting tools, optical components, and electronics. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, i.e., its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This is achieved by strain engineering, which is a promising route to tailor the properties of diamond. Our findings open up new opportunities for diamond applications in electronics and photonics. They also provide a platform for further studies on the properties of other materials. This work is expected to have a broad impact on the scientific community.

This study provides a structural and functional characterization of a unique peptide, NCR044, from the legume Medicago truncatula. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is dynamic and that the proteome of the female reproductive tract is a major source of proteins that associate with sperm. These findings provide a comprehensive understanding of the male–female interface and may be broadly applicable to other species. This work also provides a resource for future studies of the molecular interactions between sperm and the female reproductive tract. (Show more)

Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the role of viruses in human health has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses from human samples, which can be used to study the role of viruses in human disease. The database includes information on the viral taxa, the samples in which they were found, and the clinical conditions of the patients. This resource will be useful for researchers studying the role of viruses in human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process, which is difficult to be observed. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The origin and evolution of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. This question is of particular importance in the context of the recent discovery of the oldest life on Earth, which is estimated to be 3.4 billion years old. The study of the origin and evolution of life is further complicated by the fact that the fossil record is incomplete and that the fossil record that we do have is biased toward organisms that are preserved in sedimentary rocks. This study provides a new method for reconstructing the temperature history of Earth over geological time.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and cell function. They open and close their pores to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. C-type inactivation in BK channels occurs during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or with decreased intracellular calcium ([Ca2+]i) and recovers with depolarized membrane potentials or elevated [Ca2+]i. This finding suggests that C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel gating and may lead to the development of new drugs for treating diseases. This article is protected by copyright. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up the possibility of new therapeutic strategies to combat this disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical stability. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering. This opens up opportunities to tailor the properties of diamond for applications.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity was observed in multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal language-related areas, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Formal model comparison indicated that the model of multiword phrase construction provided a better fit than probability-based models at most sites in superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices. Activity in those regions was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway for cell fate decisions in the developing embryo. It is also a pathway that is dysregulated in many cancers. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its function is to convert signals at the plasma membrane to signals that inhibit the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, and that this differential regulation is important for tissue-specific responses. This may be a general feature of redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

This study provides a detailed characterization of the brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. The study also provides a new model for the study of the brain circuits that regulate eating behavior.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of biologically fixed nitrogen to the plant, without the need for chemical fertilizers. Here, we have developed a system that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. This system is based on the production of a signaling molecule by the plant, which is recognized by the bacteria. This system is a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by facilitating transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results from the experiment are not statistically significant. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web is an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured, dynamic, and highly sensitive acoustic sensor. The spider can hear without a body, and it can hear without a body that is made of protein.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C

We show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the skin and the eye. We further show that the three zebrafish ALK/Ltk ligands are expressed in the same tissue and that they are required for the development of iridophores. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/Ltk receptors in neural crest development. This finding is of importance for the understanding of the role of ALK/Ltk signaling in human cancer and in the development of human diseases.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for some of the deadliest outbreaks in human history. The emergence of Y. pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most important events in the history of human disease, and the study of its evolution is crucial to understanding the origins of this disease. Here, we present the genomes of 17 Y. pestis strains from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which provide a unique snapshot of the pathogen’s evolution during this critical period. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage, which was replaced by a lineage adapted to fleas. This study provides a more complete picture of the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its vector. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The conversion of grasslands to intensive crop production has led to massive losses of soil carbon (C) to the atmosphere. This study shows that the adoption of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems can mitigate these losses. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and manure addition. These practices can be effective in increasing soil organic carbon storage and the use of soil organic matter by soil microbes. This study highlights the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change and provides a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. This framework can be applied to other regions and soil types and can be used to assess the potential of alternative agricultural systems to mitigate climate change. (Show more)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification and prioritization of zoonotic threats to human health.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. The first nectar produced is acidic and pale yellow in color, but slowly becomes alkaline before taking on its characteristic red color. Three enzymes secreted into the nectar are either necessary or sufficient for pigment production, including a carbonic anhydrase that increases nectar pH, an aryl-alcohol oxidase that produces a pigment precursor, and a ferritin-like catalase that protects the pigment from degradation by hydrogen peroxide. Our findings identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. We present a study of the genetic ancestry of a group of women who lived in Bavaria, Germany, during the early medieval period. We find that the genetic ancestry of these women is highly heterogeneous, and that some of them have a very high degree of genetic similarity to women from present-day southeastern Europe. This is surprising, as it was previously thought that the genetic ancestry of women in Europe today is mostly of northern European origin. In addition, we find that some of the women had a genetic ancestry that was very different from that of men, and that this was not the case for modern women. These findings suggest that the genetic ancestry of women in Europe today is not only the result of recent migration, but also of a long history of migration that occurred during the early medieval period.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and may contribute to the development of more effective strategies for the prevention and control of future bat coronavirus

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common clinical category, and that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, were also detected. Early detection of chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. This study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential for rapid public health response. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a blueprint for future pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in the nucleus of the cell. This process is essential for the survival of the cell and the organism. The process is complex and requires the cooperation of many proteins. One of the most important proteins is the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). PCNA is essential for the replication of the lagging strand of DNA. It is also essential for the repair of DNA lesions. We have developed a series of assays to study the interaction of PCNA with DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). These assays allow us to study the interaction of pol δ with PCNA in a way that has not been possible before. We have found that pol δ is not as stable as previously thought. This has implications for the replication of DNA and the repair of DNA lesions.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, the evolution of proteins has been studied extensively, but the evolution of RNA-based life has been difficult to achieve. Here, we report the evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules from an RNA template. This is the first step toward the evolution of an RNA-based life cycle.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are related to the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and reduce mortality. This study provides a new therapeutic strategy for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its role in the regulation of microbial interactions is poorly understood. Here we report the existence of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work provides a new perspective on the role of natural products in the regulation of microbial interactions and the potential for the development of new antifungal agents. This work also demonstrates the utility of the synthetic biology platform for the discovery of new natural products. This platform can be applied to other fungal natural products and to the study of the role of natural products in the regulation of microbial interactions in general. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, on Mars is surprising. Tridymite is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and the presence of such a mineral in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment is consistent with the presence of a silicic volcanic source in the region. The presence of amorphous silica, possibly precipitated from acidic solutions, is consistent with the presence of acidic solutions in the region. The presence of magnetite, possibly derived from a silicic volcanic source, is consistent with the presence of silicic volcanism in the region. The presence of mixed-cation salts and oxides, possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions, is consistent with the presence of multiple aqueous solutions in the region. These findings are consistent with the hypothesis that the region was a site of intense aqueous and/or volcanic activity. (Less)

Frost events are a major threat to plants and animals in the temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is not uniform across the region. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are not uniform across the region, and that this resistance is changing. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the development of this disease is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the dual action of Th17 cells: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by motor neuron toxicity. However, the mechanisms of motor neuron toxicity are not well understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study the disease process and to screen for therapeutics. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify therapeutics for ALS. This will lead to the development of new therapies for ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. This work will also provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of motor neuron toxicity in other neurodegenerative diseases. This will lead to the development of new therapies for ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropods is a complex community that plays a critical role in the health of the host. In this study, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis, modifies the gut microbiota of the vector tick Ixodes scapularis. We demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the gut microbiota to facilitate its colonization of the tick. We also show that the bacterium induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the integrity of the gut microbiota and the peritrophic matrix, two critical barriers for the colonization of the pathogen. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of vectors. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful animal groups, and the study of their evolution is one of the most important areas of research in paleontology. The study of the origin of the modern avian bauplan is particularly important, as it is the basis for understanding the evolution of flight and the origin of the modern bird family tree. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and show that it represents an important step in the evolution of the avian bauplan.
