Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of these colors are used for camouflage. In this study, we show that the color of some vertebrates can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein is found in many different species and has a unique function. We also show that this protein has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution. This discovery is important because it shows that the color of vertebrates is not fixed, but can be changed by evolution.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and recurrence of the disease. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is increased in BCSCs, and hypoxia induces ALKBH5 expression in a HIF-dependent manner. ALKBH5 expression increases the percentage of BCSCs, and hypoxia reduces the percentage of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 expression mediates the enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the maintenance of BCSCs. Understanding this mechanism may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. This controversy has been fueled by the use of the Latin term abortivum in many sources, which has led some scholars to suggest that the skins were used for the production of pocket Bibles. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is one of the most important questions in the study of the origin of life. The age model for the extinction is based on a new set of U-Pb dates from the Meishan section in China. The dates confirm that the extinction occurred between 251.9 and 251.8 Ma, and that the carbon cycle was highly volatile immediately preceding the extinction. The dates also confirm that the carbon cycle was highly volatile immediately preceding the extinction. The dates also confirm that the carbon cycle was highly volatile immediately preceding the extinction. This work will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. It will also establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is a complex disease with a high incidence and a high rate of recurrence. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and not fully understood. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in the intestinal epithelium (IE) and is involved in the regulation of intestinal inflammation. RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the human ACE2 receptor, and we show that the D614G mutation has little effect on the structure of the complex. However, we find that the mutant spike is more flexible and can adopt a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike glycoprotein. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 0.7 y higher in 2020, and at age 65 y, 0.87 y higher. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings underscore the importance of addressing structural inequalities in order to reduce the burden of COVID-19 and improve health outcomes in the United States.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are the starting point for the study of chemical reactions and the understanding of the properties of compounds. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. Furthermore, we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. This work is a major step forward in the understanding of the chemical properties of atoms and the chemistry of matter under pressure. It is also a major step forward in the understanding of the chemistry of the elements.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the sign of the effect is uncertain. We show that, in some regions, climate change may reduce fire activity, which in turn may reduce warming. This is because fire emissions are a strong feedback to the global carbon cycle. Our results suggest that climate change may be less of a threat to the climate if we reduce emissions of greenhouse gases.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a symbiont in a mutualism between a squid and its luminescent bacterium. This glycan is released by host cells in a specific manner, which is only established after the squid has colonized its host for a sufficient period of time. This glycan is then catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This work provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbioses and the potential for the use of glycans as a means of controlling the activities of microbes in the body. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which have led to the development of word embeddings. We show that word embeddings can be used to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent variables. We also show that these latent topics can be used to model the gendered nature of topics. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and it can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to model the gendered nature of topics.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in European history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that this epidemic was preceded by a series of climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis provides evidence for the existence of a network of plague reservoirs in Asia, which were repeatedly repopulated by the bacterium over the course of the second plague pandemic. This network was not limited to the ancient Silk Road, but also included the Indian Ocean trade routes. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of a series of repeated introductions of Y. pestis into Europe, rather than the consequence of a single introduction. This conclusion has important implications for our understanding of the history of the plague and its impact on European society.

The sea-star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases of marine invertebrates. It has been observed in at least 20 species of asteroids, and the disease has been spreading rapidly in some areas. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus in asteroids, and it is the first report of a densovirus in a marine invertebrate. The discovery of a densovirus in a marine invertebrate has important implications for the evolution of the virus and for the spread of the virus in the marine environment.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common forms of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP as a treatment for AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island was settled by different groups from Africa and Asia. The settlement history is complex, and the island was settled by different groups at different times. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the history of Madagascar, and it is a step forward to understand the history of the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate gene expression. Some of these RNAs encode a small protein, which has been shown to have a function in addition to its RNA-based function. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We also show that the RNA also regulates the expression of genes involved in carbon utilization. This is the first example of a dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in bacteria.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have the potential to evade the immune protection provided by vaccines and prior infection. This study demonstrates the use of a deep learning algorithm to improve the neutralizing activity of an antibody against VOCs. The algorithm can be used to optimize the sequence of the antibody’s CDR regions, which are the most important part of the antibody that binds to the virus. The optimized antibody can then be used to develop an antibody drug candidate to combat the spread of VOCs. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules, such as vaccines, and may help to combat future pandemics.

We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, meaning that it changes in response to experience. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We also show that it is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. Our findings provide a new perspective on the evolution of the plastid genome and its relationship to the origin of life. They also provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the genome of the most complex organisms on Earth, the plants. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was the most severe in the city’s history and the first time that the city was threatened with running out of water. The drought was preceded by three consecutive dry winters, which were caused by a combination of natural variability and anthropogenic climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. This increase in drought risk will continue to increase under high-emission scenarios. Our results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This sensitivity is due to the small size of the region and the high variability of rainfall. Our results are important for water resource management in SSA and for the design of adaptation strategies. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been one of the most important developments in the science of the 20th and 21st centuries. This paper describes the discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, which was formed in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion.

Photosynthesis is the primary source of chemical energy on Earth. The capture of solar energy is accomplished by chlorophyll, a reaction that is dependent on the formation of a unique fifth ring, the isocyclic ring. The biosynthesis of this ring is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is the rate-limiting component of photosynthesis. This study reveals the evolution of this enzyme, and its role in photosynthesis. (Contains figures and tables.)

Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1). However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes exacerbates neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a minor role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation. These findings provide a rationale for targeting ASK1 in microglia/macrophages as a potential therapeutic strategy for MS. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. Climate model experiments with and without anthropogenic forcings reveal that human activities have increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. Further, a large ensemble of climate model realizations reveals that additional global warming over the next few decades is very likely to create ∼100% probability that any annual-scale dry period is also extremely

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes. It is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. Here, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a molecular mechanism for autism and may contribute to the development of new treatments. This study also provides a generalizable approach for identifying the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. In the process, it offers a more nuanced understanding of the role of negativity biases in shaping the news media.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 are associated with severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel, which are associated with Stormorken syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell autonomous and that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The results also provide a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and may have implications for the development of antiviral strategies in bats and humans. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and may have implications for the development of antiviral strategies in bats and humans.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit cycle, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the enzyme has been the target of small-molecule inhibitors. Here we report the discovery of dual SHMT1/2 inhibitors, which are effective in vitro and in vivo. We also report a unique sensitivity of B-cell lymphoma cell lines to SHMT inhibition, which is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a foundation for the development of metabolic inhibitors of cancer. (Show more)

The presence of coaggregating proteins in the intracellular inclusions of ALS patients has been a puzzle for more than a decade. Here, we show that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is not well understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of Spain in the 1900s. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The study of Montsechia raises questions about the very early divergence of the flowering plants and the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of the flowering plants. This research opens the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the early evolution of the flowering plants. (Less)

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to both virologists and evolutionary biologists. However, the study of virus evolution is complicated by the fact that viruses are typically very small and, as a result, have short genetic sequences. Here we present the genomes of five individuals who lived between ∼0.5 and ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily for the last 25 y, and this rise is accelerating. This acceleration is due to the combined effects of climate change and the Earth’s internal deformation. We find that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, and that the climate-change–driven rate of sea level rise is 2.9 ± 0.4 mm/y. These results are in agreement with the IPCC AR5 model projections.

Pain is a major public health problem, and the number of Americans reporting pain is increasing. However, the increase is not uniform across the population. Pain is more common in the youngest cohorts of adults, and the gap between the youngest and oldest cohorts is widening. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. It is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication that has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection provides a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also provides a proof of concept for the use of nonhuman primates as a model for MERS-CoV infection. This model may be used to test the efficacy of other antiviral treatments. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activity of a symbiotic luminescent bacterium. This glycan is released by host cells in the hours before dusk, when the symbiont population is at its lowest level. We propose that this strategy is used by animals to regulate the activity of their symbionts, and that it may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activity of their symbionts. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbioses. (Show more)

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in schools. This is a major public health problem, and the results are encouraging. They also suggest that it is possible to change the mindsets of teachers, which is a major obstacle to reducing suspension rates. This is a scalable intervention.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to mutagenesis and transcriptional stalling. However, the molecular mechanism of how DNA alkylation affects transcription remains unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of DNA alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription of alkylated DNA is controlled by multiple fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of MERS S proteins is required for efficient infection of human lung-derived cells, but not for infection into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Therefore, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may also be relevant to other coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available by 50% could lead to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% in a cafeteria with 1,000 diners per day. This is a large increase, and it is likely that the proportional increase would be even larger in cafeterias with more diners. The results also suggest that the intervention had no detectable rebound effect. This study provides evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we use a combination of mass spectrometry and activated ion electron transfer dissociation to study the surfaceome of a panel of six oncogenes in a single cell line. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major step forward in understanding the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome in cancer. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that its effects are likely to be modest.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can lead to cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex to trigger the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), which contribute to the development of edema. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that the hypoxic release of CRF could be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. This study provides a molecular understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of this condition. (Show more)

The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being generated is growing exponentially. The sophistication of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is also growing exponentially. This paper describes a new challenge that this revolution presents to science. It is the challenge of “selective inference.” We must be able to declare the strength of associations that we find in the face of the fact that we have “cherry picked” the data. This paper describes some recent developments in selective inference and illustrates their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. Although many transcription factors have been identified, the minimum number of factors that are required for the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is sufficient to induce the conversion of primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks for regenerative medicine. Furthermore, ETV2-induced ECs can improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model. These results indicate that ETV2 is a promising therapeutic target for the treatment of ischemic disorders. (Show more)

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a large family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a variety of physiological processes. In the last decade, two new RTKs have been identified, ALK1 and Ltk, which are involved in the development of the eye and the skin. Here, we show that these two RTKs are involved in a third process, pigmentation. We also show that these two RTKs are involved in the same process in zebrafish, but not in mammals. This study demonstrates that zebrafish are a powerful model for the study of the role of RTKs in pigmentation. It also provides a new example of a third RTK involved in the same process in different species. Finally, it demonstrates that zebrafish are a powerful model for the study of the role of RTKs in pigmentation.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in peripheral tissues beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance. Surprisingly, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Moreover, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in STING-deficient β-cells. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza and are responsible for occasional pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and takes place in infected cells. We also show that this interaction favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides a molecular understanding of the selective packaging mechanism of influenza A virus. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The development of these lesions is a multistep process that involves the accumulation of atheroprone phenotypes in the arterial wall. The objective of this study was to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is one of the most destructive natural processes in the United States. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely played a role in the increase in wildfire activity. However, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that people have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are related to the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, but the recent availability of a nonhuman primate model has allowed for the study of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model can be used to estimate the basic reproductive number R0, the rate of viral production, and the time between cell infection and viral production. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. This model can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of anthropogenic and natural stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. It is also the site of the immune system’s first line of defense. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors. These tumors trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn triggers the growth of the tumors. We also show that the microbiome can trigger this feedback loop. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling in the epithelium to maintain the integrity of the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to treat intestinal tumors. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes involved in the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and that this expression is associated with the enhanced capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is more effective than treatment with chemotherapy alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most important questions in the history of the Earth system. We show that the start of deglaciation was triggered by a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a poleward shift of the westerlies.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries catches, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, many of whom are poor and undernourished. This highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to improve fishery management and protect the benefits that rivers provide to people and wildlife.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate is a defining characteristic of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost after birth. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the sensory dendrite, and it is enhanced by disrupting calcium signaling and elevating cAMP. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration is a powerful platform for the discovery of new genes involved in the regulation of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the adult nervous system may be more regenerative than previously thought. This study also provides a framework for understanding the relationship between regeneration and plasticity in the adult nervous system.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. It is also the target of many human diseases. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of recombination is similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the process of recombination has been conserved in evolution.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the generation of cognitive functions. However, the functional significance of these networks is still unclear. Here, we show that the organization of the brain into functional networks can be directly measured in healthy subjects and in patients with Parkinson’s disease. This organization is related to the metabolic activity of the brain, and it is altered in the early stages of the disease. This approach can be used to study the functional significance of the brain organization, and to monitor the progression of the disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the primary modification that regulates the stability and translation of mRNA in eukaryotes. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery is important for understanding the role of NAD+ in the regulation of gene expression. It also provides a foundation for future studies of the role of NAD+ in the regulation of metabolism and aging. (Show more)

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We found that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and may be associated with metabolic memory. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to improve the long-term control of diabetes.

This study provides evidence that the expression of the protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is associated with poor prognosis in patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). Furthermore, we show that FSIP1 is involved in the regulation of autophagy and the AMPK pathway, which are both important in the response to chemotherapy. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of TNBC. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the severity of psychological symptoms. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence, and that the gut barrier and the microbiota may be potential targets in the management of this disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is the result of the combined action of many volatile chemicals. These chemicals are produced by a variety of metabolic pathways, some of which are known, while others are not. This study describes the identification of a gene essential for the production of a group of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of a unique class of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in a variety of disciplines. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem change and biodiversity loss. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem change and biodiversity loss. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large population of neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner, and the organization of these neurons is thought to be important for navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of this population is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the organization of place cells is different from that of other neurons in MEC. This work provides a new tool for studying the organization of the place cell population in the MEC. It also provides a model for future studies of the organization of other large-scale neuronal populations in the brain.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts. This may be an important mechanism for the success of this parasite.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is characterized by motor symptoms, including tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia, and by nonmotor symptoms, including depression, anxiety, and sleep disorders. The disease is also associated with a wide range of psychiatric disorders, including schizophrenia, which is itself a disorder of the dopamine system. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system in the brain that is involved in the control of mood and motivation.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether they feel connected. This signal is used by both the people being responded to and the people doing the responding. This finding has implications for our understanding of the nature of social connection, as well as for the design of social technologies.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are characterized by their unique electrophysiological properties. The SAN is also the site of the cardiac pacemaker potential, which is generated by a network of voltage-gated ion channels. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This work provides insight into the mechanisms that regulate SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of two key genes involved in the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. This interaction between Si and JA was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of JA biosynthesis by Si. These results provide insights into the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These findings may have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the treatment of phenylketonuria. They also suggest that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase may be a target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. (Show more)

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. This mechanism is not dependent on synaptic plasticity or persistent activity, and it is not limited to a single memory store. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biology and nanotechnology communities. (Show more)

Eutrophication is one of the greatest threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of this problem is driven by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large lakes. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include these overlooked sources. This could lead to a more holistic approach to managing nutrient loading and protecting the health of aquatic ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of interacting particles in a random potential, and we show that this analogy is not coincidental. We also find that the dynamics of the system are sensitive to the details of the environment, and that the system can exhibit a rich variety of behaviors depending on the details of the environment. This article is part of a special issue on “Stochastic Processes in Chemical Systems” (https://www.frontiersin.org/research-topics/13696/stochastic-processes-in-chemical-systems).

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain. It also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other neuroimmune insults on the brain.

The history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, especially in the context of the Earth system. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and that the warming was driven by an increase in nutrient availability. This study provides a new perspective on the history of abrupt climate change and the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations (∼188,000 km2) in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire from 2001 to 2015. Our results suggest that certification reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the release of proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved from bacteria to humans. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex and its regulation are not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is one of the most fundamental and conserved traits in animals. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce more than two sexes. Here we show that the interaction of multiple sex determination alleles can produce a modular system of sexual variation, where the same trait can be sexually dimorphic in one sex class and monomorphic in the other. This modular system of sexual variation is not unique to cichlid fish, but is also found in other species, including humans. Our results suggest that the maintenance of multiple sex determination alleles in a species may be a key factor in the evolution of sexual dimorphism.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct forms of reactive oxygen species. One form is generated by the oxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) by the bisretinoid lipofuscin, and the other is generated by the photooxidation of the pigment rhodopsin. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, which is a key factor in the photooxidation of rhodopsin, can influence the formation of lipofuscin and the photooxidation of rhodopsin. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the levels of iron in the retina can be manipulated to influence the formation of lipofuscin and the photooxidation of rhodopsin. This may lead to the development of new therapies for age-related macular degeneration. (truncated)

Predators are the key to understanding the evolution of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a stepping stone to the evolution of new predatory niches. Our findings contribute to a broader understanding of the evolution of predatory niches, and help us to understand how biodiversity is structured in the present-day food web.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding is important for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of the distinctive human lifestyle.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit cycle, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the enzyme has been the target of small-molecule inhibitors. Here we report the discovery of dual SHMT1/2 inhibitors, which are effective in vitro and in vivo. We also report a unique sensitivity of B-cell lymphoma cell lines to SHMT inhibition, which is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a foundation for the development of metabolic inhibitors for cancer therapy. This study provides evidence that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This is a significant finding, given that the literature on the relationship between deforestation and food security is mixed. The results have important implications for policy makers, who have been slow to recognize the potential of forests to improve people’s diets. The results also have implications for the broader literature on the relationship between deforestation and food security, which has been dominated by studies that focus on the supply side of food, rather than the demand side.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, allowing for vastly expanded food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
